column1: It’s been a rocky start to the year for Bitcoin
column2: but experts still say it will hit $100
column3: 000 — and that it’s more a matter of when
column4: not if.

column1: Bitcoin’s price surged above $23
column2: 000 on Wednesday after the Federal Reserve decided to take a more aggressive plan of action by raising interest rates by 0.75% and an economic report revealed the U.S. GDP fell for two consecutive quarters. The upward price movement suggests that investors were already expecting those two outcomes this week. The largest crypto is up more than 10% in the last 24 hours.

column1: “The FOMC decision provided optimism that the end of tightening is in sight and that triggered a nice rally for risky assets that helped elevate cryptos
column2: ” says Edward Moya
column3: a senior market analyst at broker Oanda. “A clear greenlight to buy up risky assets won’t happen until we see evidence inflation is coming down.”

column1: Moya says Bitcoin is showing some signs of stabilizing lately
column2: but the market may not be out of the danger zone yet. Bitcoin has fallen below $20
column3: 000 — a key price point — several times in recent weeks and the “majority of crypto watchers are still awaiting further weakness and possible retest of the June lows
column4: ” he says.

column1: The latest crypto market crash in June was spurred by momentary de-risking from Wall Street as many investors are feeling pessimistic about the economy amid surging inflation
column2: a shaky stock market
column3: and rising interest rates. The crypto market has increasingly tracked the stock market in recent months
column4: which makes it even more intertwined with global economic factors.

column1: In addition to macroeconomic factors
column2: Martin Hiesboeck
column3: head of blockchain and crypto research at Uphold
column4: says investors fear the crypto industry’s long-term viability after several major crypto players halted withdrawals
column5: cut jobs
column6: and tried to stem losses in recent weeks. However
column7: crypto prices are much more vulnerable to factors contributing to the difficult economic situation than the pullback in the crypto ecosystem

column1: “The market remains vulnerable and on edge
column2: not necessarily by threats from more crypto projects going bust but from the difficult economic situation we are facing right now
column3: ” Hiesboeck says. “In other words
column4: the price of bitcoin depends more on the supply of gas to Germany as it does in any crypto-related news or metric.”

column1: With no end in sight
column2: the war
column3: inflation
column4: and shifting monetary policy in the U.S. will likely continue to drive more volatility in the coming weeks and months
column5: experts say.

column1: Bitcoin has only been above $45
column2: 000 for a few short stretches over the past six months
column3: and hasn’t been above $50
column4: 000 since Dec. 25
column5: 2021. Amid the ups and downs
column6: Bitcoin’s current price is a long way off from the latest all-time high it hit in November
column7: when it went over $68
column8: 000. But even with the recent decline in price
column9: Bitcoin is still more than twice as valuable as it was just a couple years ago. For Bitcoin
column10: these kinds of ups and downs are nothing new.

column1: One Week Ago (July 22) One Month Ago (June 29) 3 Months Ago (April 30) $23
Prices updated: July 29
Despite the volatility and recent slumping price
column2: many experts still say Bitcoin is on its way to passing the $100
column3: 000 mark
column4: though with varying opinions on exactly when that will happen. And a recent study by Deutsche Bank found that about a quarter of Bitcoin investors believe Bitcoin prices will be over $110
column5: 000 in five years.

column1: The volatility is nothing new
column2: and is a big reason experts say new crypto investors should be extremely cautious when allocating part of their portfolio to cryptocurrency. Bitcoin has shown as steady a rise in value over the years as any other cryptocurrency on the market. It’s only reasonable for Bitcoin investors to be curious about how high it can ultimately go.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: Bitcoin’s price is extremely difficult to predict and even more susceptible to market factors than more established asset classes. But we decided to ask some experts for their best guesses anyway. Here’s what they said:

column1: Bitcoin Price Predictions
It was easy to predict a $100
column2: 000 Bitcoin price late last year
column3: coming off its latest all-time high in November. With Bitcoin’s big fall since then
column4: the prediction game is even trickier.

column1: The most extreme crypto skeptics say Bitcoin will tank to as low as $10
column3: but a middle ground might be to say the cryptocurrency can still climb to $100
column4: 000 like many experts predicted late last year — just on a slower timeline.

column1: “The most knowledgeable educators in the space are predicting $100
column2: 000 Bitcoin in Q1 2022 or sooner
column3: ” Kate Waltman
column4: a New York-based certified public accountant who specializes in crypto
column5: told us back in November 2021.

column1: But now
column2: bullish experts are re-evaluating the crypto industry altogether as major corporations like Nike and other big brands are looking at ways to monetize their products in the digital metaverse. The rise of metaverse games
column3: worlds
column4: products
column5: and experiences is increasing the popularity of altcoins
column6: which has changed investors’ sentiments about Bitcoin (known as the original crypto).

column1: Many experts are hesitant to predict a number and a date
column2: but rather point to the trend of Bitcoin increasing its value over time. Investors should expect a “pretty sustainable” rise in Bitcoin’s long-term value driven by organic market movement
column3: with the $100
column4: 000 threshold in near-sight
column5: predicted Jurrien Timmer
column6: director of global macro at Fidelity Investments
column7: last October.

column1: “What I expect from Bitcoin is volatility [in the] short-term and growth [in the] long-term
column2: ” says Kiana Danial
column3: founder of Invest Diva and author of “Cryptocurrency Investing For Dummies.”

column1: Here are some more predictions we found
column2: ranked from low to high over the next year:

column1: Ian Balina
Point of View: Bitcoin investor and founder of crypto research and media company Token Metrics
Bitcoin investor and founder of crypto research and media company Token Metrics Prediction: Bitcoin can go to $100
column4: but the timeline is unclear

column1: Bitcoin can go to $100
column4: but the timeline is unclear Why: Bitcoin is in a bearish sentiment cycle
column5: but the total crypto market and other crypto asset classes are not. Bitcoin was the first cryptocurrency
column6: but now others have surpassed it in innovation when it comes to what experts call “Web 3” — aka the new internet built on blockchain. The release of new altcoins and hype about the metaverse will continue to drive the demand for crypto
column7: and Bitcoin will therefore bounce back eventually.

column1: Matthew Hyland
Point of View: Technical analysis and blockchain data analyst
Technical analysis and blockchain data analyst Prediction: Bitcoin can reach $100
Bitcoin can reach $100
column2: 000 in 2022 Why: The price of Bitcoin in January 2022 is almost equal to its price in January 2021
column3: but there’s a new demand for altcoins. There’s also an ongoing trend of Bitcoin supply leaving major exchanges (presumably to be stored in offline crypto wallets)
column4: Hyland said in a tweet. He also recently tweeted that a dip below $40
column5: 000 could lead to “free fall” into a Bitcoin bear market.

column1: Robert Breedlove
Point of View: Founder and CEO of the digital assets marketing and consulting firm Parallax Digital
Founder and CEO of the digital assets marketing and consulting firm Parallax Digital Prediction: $307
column2: 000 by October 2021 (now passed)
column3: and $12.5 million by 2031

column2: 000 by October 2021 (now passed)
column3: and $12.5 million by 2031 Why: Inflationary pressures after COVID-19 will drive interest in cryptocurrency
column4: pushing the value of Bitcoin up higher than previous projections estimated
column5: Breedlove said in an interview earlier this year. Known as more of a philosopher type among crypto enthusiasts
column6: Breedlove speaks often about the broader social implications of crypto as a form of more transparent
column7: decentralized currency — but his price predictions haven’t exactly been spot-on.

column1: Big financial institutions have made their own predictions
column2: as well
column3: with JPMorgan predicting a long-term high of $146
column4: 000 and Bloomberg predicting it could hit $400
column5: 000 if the currency climbs at rates comparable to the past.

column1: Pro Tip Even if Bitcoin breaks $100
column3: stay focused building on your overall portfolio including passive index funds
column4: emergency savings
column5: and your retirement account(s).

column1: What Influences Bitcoin’s Price
Normal economic factors influence the price of cryptocurrency just like any other currency or investment — supply and demand
column2: public sentiment
column3: the news cycle
column4: market events
column5: scarcity
column6: and more.

column1: As a new and emerging asset
column2: additional factors influence Bitcoin’s value more than the average currency or security. Here are some:

column1: Scarcity
There are only 18 to 19 million Bitcoins currently in circulation
column2: and minting will stop at 21 million. Industry experts consistently point to this built-in scarcity as a big part of cryptocurrency’s appeal.

column1: “There’s a fixed supply but increasing demand
column2: ” says Alexis Johnson
column3: president of the blockchain public relations and events company
column4: Light Node Media.

column1: Other experts point out Bitcoin has value because people give it value. “That’s really why everybody’s buying — because of the psychological aspect
column2: ” says Nelson Merchan
column3: Johnson’s Light Node Media co-founder. That can make it difficult for the average consumer to discern whether Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies are legitimate. The whole concept of supply and demand only works when people want something scarce — even if it previously didn’t exist.

column1: “It actually does almost kind of seem like a scam
column2: ” Merchan says about Bitcoin’s origins. Though he says he’s seen his crypto holdings reach millions at times since he began investing in 2017
column3: he’s also seen them disappear in an instant.

column1: “I’m a big believer that if it’s not in cash
column2: you don’t really have that money because in crypto
column3: anything can drop dramatically overnight
column4: ” Merchan says. This is why certified financial planners suggest only allocating 1% to 5% of your portfolio to crypto — to protect your money from the volatility.

column1: Mainstream Adoption
One of the main factors driving the price increase of Bitcoin is the rate at which new consumers are buying and exploring cryptocurrency
column2: says Waltman.

column1: “Crypto technology is being adopted at a faster rate than humans first adopted internet technology
column2: ” she says. Assuming it continues
column3: the compounding acceleration of new adoption could keep pushing the value of Bitcoin higher and higher.

column1: Bitcoin adoption has been increasing at an annual rate of 113%
column2: according to data from the digital asset management firm CoinShares. (Meanwhile
column3: people adopted the internet at a slower rate of 63%.) If people warm up to Bitcoin at a comparable rate to that of the internet’s early days (or faster)
column4: the report makes the case that there will be 1 billion users by 2024 and 4 billion users by 2030.

column1: CoinDesk reported last month the number of new wallets worldwide increased 45% from January 2020 to January 2021
column2: to an estimated 66 million. Popular crypto exchange Coinbase says it has now over 73 million worldwide users
column3: while fellow exchange Gemini recently released its “State of U.S. Crypto Report
column4: ” which found 21.2 million Americans own cryptocurrency of some kind.

column1: Regulation

Federal officials have made it clear in recent months they are paying attention to crypto. Industry professionals have recently alluded to what crypto insiders perceive as “hawkish” federal regulation being one key driver for Bitcoin’s lagging price. In a recent CoinDesk First Mover interview
column2: Seth Ginns
column3: a CoinFund managing partner
column4: said “the Fed moved to a hawkish position [on crypto regulation] just as Omicron started to tick up in the U.S.
column5: ” which could have increased doubt in crypto as a viable asset—resulting in January’s bearish sentiments.

column1: Crypto regulation brings up a lot of unanswered questions. President Joe Biden recently signed an infrastructure bill requiring all crypto exchanges to notify the IRS of their transactions. Similarly
column2: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen recently said stablecoins — a type of crypto linked to the value of the U.S. dollar — should be subject to federal oversight.

column1: The conversation on regulatory policies is “patchy
column2: ” said an industry white paper published by Flourish
column3: a fintech platform designed for investment advisors. With a relatively new asset class like cryptocurrency
column4: any new regulation has potential to impact value.

column1: When China banned crypto in September 2021
column2: for instance
column3: investors saw the price of Bitcoin drop
column4: though it has since risen and resumed its usual volatility. Even though there’s now about a decade of precedent for Bitcoin
column5: the Securities and Exchange Commission is taking all decisions on a case-by-base basis in what experts refer to as its “crawl
column6: walk
column7: run” strategy toward mainstream crypto adoption.

column1: “[Regulation has] kind of evolved over the last five years
column2: ” says Ben Cruikshank
column3: head of Flourish
column4: “Regulators can always change their mind.”

column1: Mining Cycles
Finally
column2: another major influence on Bitcoin’s price is a cycle known as halving. It’s complicated and algorithmic in nature
column3: but in essence halving is a step in the Bitcoin mining process that results in the reward for mining Bitcoin transactions getting cut in half.

column1: Halving influences the rate at which new coins enter circulation
column2: which can impact the value of existing Bitcoin holdings. Historically
column3: halvings have correlated with boom and bust cycles. Some experts try to predict these cycles down to the day after a halving event concludes.

column1: What Investors Need to Know About Bitcoin Price Projections
As with any investment
column2: financial planners and other experts advise against letting Bitcoin’s price fluctuations lead you to emotional decision making. Studies have shown investors who contribute regularly to passive index funds and ETFs perform better over time
column3: thanks to a strategy called dollar cost averaging.

column1: That’s part of why experts recommend not investing more than 5% of your overall portfolio in cryptocurrency
column2: and never to invest at the expense of saving for emergencies and paying down high-interest debt. The path to long-term wealth and saving for retirement is most often successful for people with diversified investments like low-cost index funds
column3: with crypto making up a very small part.

column1: And even with crypto
column2: experts say a set-it-and-forget-it approach makes sense. “Passive investing is a very valid way to achieve financial goals
column3: ” says Arkansas-based certified financial planner Sarah Catherine Gutierrez.

column1: Since crypto is still new to most people
column2: it’s OK to wait and see how things unfold before putting your money on the line. We only have about 10 years of data to inform crypto price predictions
column3: and the value of Bitcoin — while potentially climbing long-term — is highly volatile from day to day.

column1: Volatility makes it hard to know the “what” and “why” behind your crypto strategy. Before investing in Bitcoin or any alternative assets
column2: ask yourself what you want to achieve from your participation in this particularly volatile market
column3: and why. That will help you stay focused.

column1: “I don’t think people understand across the board how to value [Bitcoin]
column2: ” says Gutierrez. “When you’re buying it
column3: you need to know your expectation of what value you’re going to get from what you’re buying.”

column1: Financial planners don’t have a bias against cryptocurrency
column2: Gutierrez says
column3: particularly if a client expresses an interest in learning about it. However
column4: you should ask yourself whether you need crypto as part of your plan. In most cases
column5: says Gutierrez
column6: the answer is no.

column1: “Our take is that we don’t think you need Bitcoin in order to reach financial goals
column2: ” she says
column3: adding that the average person should favor simple ways of investing that are easy to understand. This will keep you on track for core financial goals and better position you long-term for a healthy retirement."

column8: 'Cryptocurrency Industry Since']	"Total crypto market capitalization has shrunk by $216 billion since yesterday in a fall that has dropped it to just below $2.78 trillion according to CoinGecko.

column1: The massive wipe-out is the second of its kind this month after leveraged derivatives traders were liquidated on Nov. 11 resulting in a $125 billion slump.
On-chain analyst Dylan LeClair has again fingered leveraged positions for today’s massive slump.
The total market cap has now fallen back to early November levels as major crypto assets continue correcting from their recent all-time highs.
Bitcoin Leads the Drop
Bitcoin is leading markets into the red during the Tuesday morning Asian trading session. BTC has lost 7.3% over the past 24 hours in a fall to around $61K at the time of writing.
ADVERTISEMENT

The king of crypto has retreated 11.6% from its Nov. 10 all-time high of a touch over $69K. Pricing models such as stock-to-flow are still predicting larger gains for Bitcoin before the end of this year with a target price of $135K painted.
Despite this latest loss
column2: BTC has still more than doubled in price since the beginning of the year when it was trading at around $29K. According to Tradingview
column3: there is support at the 50-day moving average which is around the $58
column4: 800 price zone.

column1: Bitcoin’s fall comes just a day or so after its Taproot privacy upgrade went live with no issues.
Altcoins Bleeding in Crypto Plunge
As usual
column2: the rest of the crypto market is being dragged down by big brother. Ethereum has retreated 8% on the day in a tumble to $4
column3: 329 at the time of writing. ETH has now lost 11.2% from its all-time high of $4
column4: 878 also on Nov. 10.

column1: The altcoin market is a sea of red at the moment with no token in the top 50 making a gain today. Binance Coin
column2: Solana

column4: XRP
column5: and Polkadot have all lost between 6% and 11% over the past 24 hours.

column1: Larger losses are being felt by other altcoins such as Litecoin (LTC)

Lachlan Holds A Bachelor S Degree In Journalism Macleay College In Australia.']	"The crypto market was rocked this morning Asia time as news that indebted Chinese property giant Evergrande may default on a US$148 million bond payment sent prices dropping around 5% across the board. Prices stabilized throughout the day
column6: however
column7: after the firm was able to make the payment at the last moment as the grace period deadline expired yesterday. With the company around US$300 billion in debt
column8: there are concerns over the effect the company defaulting would have on global markets

column1: The price drop-off comes after days of strong price action among many leading tokens. The two largest cryptocurrencies by market cap
column2: Bitcoin and Ethereum
column3: both reached new all-time highs within hours of each other overnight before each losing more than 5% coming into business hours this morning
column4: according to data from CoinGecko. Both following very similar price movements
column5: Bitcoin reached US$69
column6: 044 just after midnight with Ethereum reaching a new level of US$4
column7: 878 shortly after.

column1: This is not the first time concerns over Evergrande’s future have caused global markets to falter. In September a similar scare saw crypto markets losing around 9% as the company debt woes made headlines around the world
column2: with the threat of its collapse
column3: eliciting comparisons to the Lehman Brothers downfall that triggered the global financial crisis in 2008. The fallout from the pending default was not as acute this time around
column4: but one market analyst told Forkast.News the company’s troubles are far from over.

column1: “Every time [Evergrande] makes a payment
column2: the clock starts ticking down for the next one
column3: and I think the market’s very much aware that it’s always going to try and use that grace period [on its loans]
column4: ” said Andrew Sullivan
column5: founder and writer for Asianmarketsense.com. “It doesn’t have enough money to pay for everything on time
column6: so it’s having to play swings and roundabouts
column7: taking money from the left pocket to the right pocket … in order to pay different suppliers

column1: With the exception of stablecoins
column2: no tokens in the top 10 by market cap were spared the downturn
column3: though some were more affected than others. Binance Coin
column4: in third position
column5: which had been making a run up on its all-time high it set back in May
column6: had been trading at its highest point since that time before dropping 10% this morning. It has since recovered and was trading at US$630 at press time
column7: according to CoinGecko.

column1: Fifth-place Solana set its own all-time high of US$259 over the weekend in the leadup to the network’s first major global conference
column2: Breakpoint
column3: which was held in Lisbon earlier this week. Among the major developments announced at the conference was a US$100 million partnership with the venture firm of Alexis Ohanian
column4: co-founder of social media site Reddit
column5: to invest in decentralized social media platforms to be built on the network. Solana saw a 7% decline in the two hours before trading this morning
column6: but has recovered swiftly and was trading back near its mid-week high at US$246 as of press time
column7: according to CoinGecko.

column1: After sitting in third position for much of the past few months in the leadup to its long-awaited Alonzo upgrade
column2: which was to bring smart contract capabilities to the network
column3: Cardano has been in slow decline since early September. An impressive price run earlier in the week seemed to suggest a change in fortunes for the network
column4: gaining 20% in a matter of days to reach a one-month high of US$2.36. Its price retreated from this point quickly
column5: however
column6: and with the 9% drop off this morning
column7: most of the gains of the past week were erased. It was trading at US$2.15 at press time

column1: While the company — like the global economy — is not out of the woods yet
column2: today’s payment has bought Evergrande some time
column3: with the next major payment not being due until early 2022. Nonetheless
column4: the company is still rife with liquidity issues and has had to resort to extreme measures to get money together. Company employees have been told they must give the firm short-term loans if they wish to receive their bonuses
column5: and company founder and chairman Xu Jiayin put a luxury house in Hong Kong he owns as loan collateral at the request of company creditors.

column1: Speculation abounds as to whether the Chinese government would allow Evergrande to fail
column2: or would step in to save the company
column3: though Sullivan does not believe that it would
column4: instead that it may attempt to apply subtle pressure to other developers to help the flailing behemoth out. Evergrande’s competitors may be disinterested in stepping in as many of the company’s projects are already pre-sold
column5: and so would yield little capital in return. While this has been done in the past
column6: it was while the markets were much healthier
column7: and Sullivan speculates some competitors may be holding off on buying any assets until the prices come down even further.

column1: The real estate market has had enormous economic and cultural value to the world’s most populous nation
column2: and if it were to collapse it would be disastrous for the country and its people. “People in China view property to a large extent as their bank
column3: this is their pension
column4: ” Sullivan said
column5: explaining as the housing market was slowing down
column6: the Chinese government was trying to shift the economy towards the production of high-end technological goods
column7: such as semiconductors.

column1: China has taken a progressively hard-line approach to cryptocurrency this year starting with a crackdown on mining throughout the country before putting a blanket ban of all cryptocurrency-related transactions in September due to the government’s belief crypto is disrupting the economic and financial order.
Sullivan said the strong market action recently could have raised tensions with would-be investors within the country
column2: but the government has taken advantage of the current moment to smooth over the cryptocurrency issue — among others.

column1: “People are naturally going to be resentful of the fact that they’ve been banned from that market
column2: ” Sullivan said. “How much they can do about it
column3: how much that’s going to sway the government [it’s] difficult to say. The thing about Covid is that it’s allowing [the government] to be very
column4: very draconian
column5: to close China down
column6: to make sure people aren’t aware of what’s going on outside so much as they would have before. So that suits [Chinese President] Xi [Jinping].”"
